Content: Primary Carcinoma of the Liver Cells (Hepatocellular Carcinoma) is a type of liver cancer that originates in the liver cells (hepatocytes). It is the most common form of liver cancer and is closely associated with chronic liver diseases, such as cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis B or C infections. Risk factors for developing hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) include heavy alcohol consumption, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), exposure to aflatoxins (toxins produced by certain molds), and genetic conditions such as hemochromatosis. It is most common in people with a history of liver disease and is more likely to occur in older adults.Symptoms of primary liver carcinoma may include jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), unexplained weight loss, upper abdominal pain or discomfort, nausea, and swelling of the abdomen due to fluid buildup. In many cases, HCC is diagnosed late when symptoms become more severe, making early detection crucial. Diagnostic procedures include blood tests (such as alpha-fetoprotein levels), imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI), and biopsy for confirmation of the cancer type.

Malignant neoplasms, or cancerous tumors, occur when cells grow uncontrollably, invading nearby tissues and spreading. Symptoms vary depending on the type but may include unexplained weight loss, fatigue, lumps, or organ-specific symptoms. Factors like genetics, environment, and lifestyle contribute to cancer risk. Treatment typically includes surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, or targeted therapies, often tailored to the cancer’s type and stage​

Psychotic Disorder refers to a mental health condition characterized by a disconnection from reality, often manifesting as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking, and impaired insight. These symptoms significantly affect a person's ability to function in daily life. Psychotic disorders can be caused by a variety of factors, including mental illnesses such as schizophrenia, mood disorders (e.g., bipolar disorder with psychotic features), substance abuse, or medical conditions like brain injuries or infections.Schizophrenia is one of the most well-known psychotic disorders, with symptoms like auditory hallucinations (hearing voices) and paranoid delusions. Delusional disorder, another type of psychotic disorder, involves fixed, false beliefs that are not rooted in reality, such as the belief that one is being persecuted or controlled by outside forces. Psychosis can also occur as a result of substance use or withdrawal (e.g., from drugs like cocaine or alcohol) or from medical conditions like tumors or neurological diseases.

Pyelonephritis is a type of urinary tract infection (UTI) that involves the kidneys. It is typically caused by bacteria ascending from the bladder into the kidneys, leading to inflammation and infection. Common symptoms include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, pain in the back or side (flank pain), painful urination, and cloudy or foul-smelling urine. In severe cases, pyelonephritis can lead to kidney damage or sepsis, a life-threatening condition caused by widespread infection in the bloodstream.Risk factors for pyelonephritis include having a history of urinary tract infections, urinary tract obstructions (such as kidney stones), anatomical abnormalities, and conditions like diabetes or a weakened immune system. Women are at higher risk, as they have a shorter urethra, making it easier for bacteria to reach the bladder and kidneys.

Respiratory failure is a condition in which your blood doesn't have enough oxygen or has too much carbon dioxide. Sometimes both problems occur. When you breathe, your lungs take in oxygen, which passes into your blood and is carried to your organs, such as the heart and brain, which need this oxygen-rich blood to function properly. Breathing also removes carbon dioxide from the blood. Too much carbon dioxide can harm organs. Symptoms of respiratory failure depend on the cause and the levels of oxygen and carbon dioxide in your blood. A low oxygen level can cause shortness of breath, air hunger (the feeling you can't breathe in enough air), and a bluish color to the skin, lips, and nails. A high carbon dioxide level can cause rapid breathing and confusion. Some people may become very sleepy or lose consciousness, and may experience arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat) if their brain and heart are not getting enough oxygen.

Sepsis is life threatening. It can be hard to spot. There are lots of possible symptoms, which can resemble those of other conditions, including flu or a chest infection. If you think you or someone you look after has symptoms of sepsis, call 999 or go to A&E. Trust your instincts.

Sickle cell anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the production of abnormal hemoglobin, called hemoglobin S. This causes red blood cells to become rigid and shaped like a crescent (or sickle), which can block blood flow in small vessels, leading to pain, organ damage, and an increased risk of infections. The most common symptoms of sickle cell anemia include episodes of pain (known as sickle cell crises), fatigue, anemia (due to the destruction of sickle cells), and swelling in the hands and feet. It primarily affects individuals of African, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and Indian ancestry.

Bronchial spasm, also known as bronchoconstriction, is the sudden constriction of the smooth muscles surrounding the airways, leading to difficulty breathing, wheezing, and coughing. This condition is common in asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and bronchitis. Bronchial spasms can occur due to triggers like allergens, respiratory infections, cold air, or exercise. In asthma, bronchoconstriction is typically reversible with the use of bronchodilators, medications that relax the airway muscles. The symptoms of bronchial spasm can vary from mild wheezing and coughing to severe shortness of breath. During a spasm, the airways narrow, which impedes airflow and makes it hard for air to enter and leave the lungs. Managing bronchial spasms often involves the use of rescue inhalers (short-acting bronchodilators) and controlling underlying conditions with long-term medications such as inhaled corticosteroids or leukotriene inhibitors.

Aortic valve stenosis (or aortic stenosis) happens when the aortic valve in your heart is narrowed or blocked. This interferes with the normal blood flow out of your heart, making your heart work harder and causing heart damage, major health problems, and even death. Replacing the valve is the best treatment and gives you a good prognosis. Aortic stenosis symptoms (progressing from less severe to more severe) include: Fatigue, which can disrupt your normal activities. Heart palpitations (being unpleasantly aware of your own heartbeat). Swelling in your feet, ankles, or lower legs. Chest pain (angina), which can also feel like squeezing, pressure or discomfort and can extend to your neck, jaw, arm or abdomen. Shortness of breath. Dizziness, lightheadedness or fainting. Your primary care provider may refer you to a cardiologist (heart doctor) if they suspect you have aortic stenosis.

A suicide attempt refers to an individual’s deliberate act of trying to end their own life, which may or may not result in injury or death. It is a serious mental health crisis and is often a manifestation of underlying issues such as depression, severe anxiety, or other psychiatric conditions. Warning signs can include extreme mood swings, withdrawal from social relationships, and expressions of hopelessness. Treatment for someone who has attempted suicide typically involves emergency medical care, psychological counseling, and long-term mental health support to address the root causes and reduce the risk of future attempts.

A systemic infection is an infection that affects the entire body rather than a localized area. These infections can spread via the bloodstream or lymphatic system, often leading to symptoms like fever, chills, fatigue, and organ dysfunction. Common causes of systemic infections include bacteria, viruses, and fungi. In severe cases, sepsis may develop, which is a life-threatening response to infection. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics, antifungals, or antiviral medications are essential, especially for infections like septicemia, which require immediate medical intervention.

Sinus tachycardia is a condition where the heart rate exceeds the normal resting rate, typically above 100 beats per minute in adults, originating from the sinus node, the natural pacemaker of the heart. It can occur as a response to various factors like fever, anxiety, physical activity, or blood loss. In some cases, it can be caused by underlying conditions such as anemia, hyperthyroidism, or heart disease. Treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause, and in some cases, medications like beta-blockers may be used to control heart rate.

Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by abnormally low levels of platelets in the blood, which can lead to increased bleeding and bruising. Causes can include bone marrow disorders, viral infections, autoimmune diseases, or certain medications. Symptoms can range from mild bruising to heavy bleeding, particularly in the gums or gastrointestinal tract. Treatment depends on the underlying cause and may include medications to increase platelet count, immune suppressants, or platelet transfusions in severe cases.

A thrombus is a blood clot that forms in a blood vessel and can obstruct blood flow, leading to conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE). Thrombosis can occur due to factors like injury to the blood vessel, slow blood flow, or changes in blood composition (such as in the case of clotting disorders). Symptoms depend on the location of the thrombus, but may include swelling, pain, redness, or difficulty breathing (in the case of a PE). Treatment typically involves anticoagulants (blood thinners) to prevent further clotting, and in some cases, clot-dissolving drugs or surgery.

Tonic-clonic epilepsy is a neurological condition characterized by recurrent seizures involving two phases: the tonic phase (muscle stiffening) and the clonic phase (muscle jerking). This type of epilepsy is often associated with generalized seizures, meaning that the abnormal electrical activity affects the entire brain. The seizures are typically caused by imbalances in neurotransmitters or brain abnormalities and may be triggered by factors like stress, sleep deprivation, or flashing lights.Symptoms include sudden loss of consciousness, followed by the body becoming stiff (tonic phase) and then jerking violently (clonic phase). After the seizure, individuals often experience confusion, fatigue, and headache. There may also be temporary memory loss and difficulty speaking or understanding language. The condition is usually managed with antiepileptic medications and sometimes lifestyle changes to reduce seizure triggers.

A tonic-clonic seizure is one of the most common types of generalized seizures, also known as grand mal seizures. It involves two stages: the tonic phase, where the muscles stiffen, followed by the clonic phase, where rapid, jerking movements of the body occur. These seizures can cause loss of consciousness, and the person may fall to the ground, leading to injury. They can last from 1 to 3 minutes and may be followed by confusion, exhaustion, or memory loss.Symptoms include loss of consciousness, muscle stiffening, jerking movements, biting the tongue, and incontinence. After the seizure, there is often a postictal period of confusion, fatigue, and disorientation. Treatment typically involves anticonvulsant medications and lifestyle modifications to prevent triggers.

Tricuspid valve insufficiency, also known as tricuspid regurgitation, is a heart valve disorder in which the tricuspid valve does not close properly, causing blood to leak backward into the right atrium of the heart. This condition can occur due to heart disease, infections, or structural problems with the valve.Symptoms may include fatigue, shortness of breath, swelling in the abdomen or legs, and heart palpitations. Severe cases can lead to right-sided heart failure, characterized by fluid retention and difficulty breathing. Treatment options include medications to manage symptoms, such as diuretics for fluid retention, and surgical interventions such as valve repair or replacement in more severe cases.

Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious bacterial infection primarily affecting the lungs but can also affect other organs such as the kidneys, spine, and brain. It is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and spreads through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes.Symptoms of active TB include a persistent cough (sometimes with blood), fever, night sweats, fatigue, weight loss, and chest pain. TB is diagnosed through a combination of medical history, chest X-rays, and sputum tests.

Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection that can spread throughout the body, affecting many organs. Without prompt treatment, it can cause serious complications and can be fatal. It's caused by a bacterium called Salmonella typhi, which is related to the bacteria that cause salmonella food poisoning. Typhoid fever is highly contagious. An infected person can pass the bacteria out of their body in their poo or, less commonly, in their pee. If someone else eats food or drinks water that's been contaminated with a small amount of infected poo or pee, they can become infected with the bacteria and develop typhoid fever.

Peptic ulcer disease is a condition that causes ulcers (open sores) to develop in the lining of your digestive tract. “Peptic” means it’s related to digestion. The word is derived from pepsin, the major digestive enzyme that your stomach produces. Pepsin and stomach acid are the active ingredients in your stomach juices that help to chemically break down food for digestion. Some of these juices also pass into the first part of your small intestine (duodenum). By design, these juices are highly corrosive. All of your gastrointestinal tract has a protective mucous lining that insulates it from the substances inside. It’s especially strong in your stomach and duodenum. But in peptic ulcer disease, this protection fails, and digestive juices corrode through the lining. Symptoms of upper gastrointestinal bleeding may include: Blood in your stool (poop). Black, tarry stool. Coffee ground vomitus. Dizziness or faintness. Pallor (paleness). Rapid heart rate. Symptoms of a gastrointestinal perforation (hole) may include: Sudden, sharp and severe abdominal pain. Abdominal swelling and tenderness to touch. Fever and chills.

An upper respiratory infection (URI) is a viral or bacterial infection that affects the nose, throat, and sinuses. It is commonly caused by viruses like rhinovirus, influenza, or RSV. Symptoms include a runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, cough, sneezing, mild fever, fatigue, headache, and watery eyes. While URIs are often self-limiting and resolve on their own, symptoms can last from a few days to two weeks. Treatment focuses on symptom relief, such as using decongestants, throat lozenges, pain relievers, and fluids. Complications like ear infections or sinusitis may arise in some cases.

Urinary tract infections (UTIs) affect your urinary tract, including your bladder (cystitis), urethra (urethritis) or kidneys (kidney infection). UTIs may be treated with antibiotics, but they're not always needed. Check if it's a urinary tract infection (UTI). Symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI) may include: pain or a burning sensation when peeing (dysuria), needing to pee more often than usual, needing to pee more often than usual during the night (nocturia), needing to pee suddenly or more urgently than usual, pee that looks cloudy, blood in your pee, lower tummy pain or pain in your back, just under the ribs, a high temperature, or feeling hot and shivery, a very low temperature below 36C. Your pee may also be dark or smell. If this is your only symptom, it might be because you've not been drinking enough water. Children
